attributes.action: Ban the Bradford Factor to manage sickness absence in the workplace
attributes.additional_details: The Bradford Factor is a formula commonly used in HR to measure employee absence. It's a number that represents how many un-planned absences an employee has taken during the last working year. An employee who takes frequent, short spells of sickness will rack up a higher Bradford Factor than an employee who has less bouts of sickness but tends to take more days off each time. This discriminates against people with chronic health conditions.
attributes.background: Make it illegal for UK employers to use "trigger" based sickness absence processes (based on the Bradford Factor) which discriminate against people with chronic, cyclical and fluctuating health conditions.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. 

Sickness absence policies are a matter for individual employers; however, employers are already required to make reasonable adjustment for disabilities including chronic health conditions, including ensuring that any sickness policies do not discriminate against people in these circumstances.
